column3: Ability to receive SUCI over the air
column4: Attacker requires sufficient signal to interference and noise ratio

column3: Improper physical security of radio access hardware
column4: Despite the virtualized structure of the 5G network and all involved network functions, there will be a strong dependency on the physical infrastructure, especially in the initial migration/hybrid 5G deployments.
The end user must not have the capability to validate whether it is communicating with a malicious DNS or a valid one.
Adversary will need to compromise keys used to sign IE modifications at IPX
Compromise of the initiating SEPP, typically the VPLMN SEPP, would permit an adversary to establish a protection policy that would allow IPX modification.
Adversary must know the SUPI or GPSI of victim UE

column2: DOS a UE via gNB or NF signaling
column4: Adversary needs access to a fake or compromised gNB or a compromised NF.
Adversaries need access to such tools.

column2: Consume data allocation to deny or degrade service
column3: A malicious app or set of apps have to have been installed on the UE
column4: There are several methods to achieve this

column3: Credential and Access to SDN Controller
column4: Privileged Access to SDN controller via direct login or through SDN control plane APIs

column3: Adversary in the same vicinity as victim gNB
column4: Adversary must be positioned in the same area as the victim gNB with a wireless sniffer device and a jamming device equipped with sufficient transmit power.
Operator environment must permit DNS queries either directly or recursively for domains the operator doesn’t directly control.
Adversary would need to be in control of the vSEPP which may be managed by a VAS
Adversaries need access to such tools.

column3: Credential and Access to repository and or image creation tools (i.e. Docker)
column4: An image can be manipulated, or a new image can be introduced to have same impact.  Privileged Access to tool or repo is required.

column3: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB
column4:
A rogue gNB may be required to change the UE’s CP and UP supported algorithms to NULL. It’s easier to achieve control over a gNB than over the AMF or SMF itself. But then if the AMF and SMF are not rogue just not configured to do these additional checks, then control over a rogue gNB is sufficient.
This attack is possible with only control over the AMF, in which case the algorithm for CP and UP protection is changed to NULL.

column3: Credential and Access to SDN vSwitch
column4: Privileged Access to SDN vSwitch via direct login or through SDN control plane APIs
Adversary may pretend to be an operator supporting only earlier generations.
Adversary has to gain control of one core NF.

column3: Knowledge of the UE SUPI or GPSI 5G-GUTI of target UE
column4: UE identifier required for all Core network function abuse.

column3: Compromised or misconfigured switches/routers or gNB
column4: Malware or wrong configuration in switches/routers between RAN and core, between gNBs, in gNB itself, in SMF or UPF.

column3: Control of fake gNB in the area where the victim UE may be located.
column4: Adversary must install a fake gNB that it can control what messages it sends to UEs.

column3: Control of fake UE  in the NAS SMC attack.
column4: Adversary must acquire a fake UE to achieve the NAS SMC attack.
Adversary needs physical access to USIM card during manufacturing of USIMs or during transport to MNOs and the cloned USIM card needs to be activated by the MNO.
Adversary may need to identify vulnerabilities in the API to obtain initial-access, unauthorized information, or perform a denial of service
Adversary may need to obtain credentials to collect unauthorized information
Adversary needs to either implant malware in SIM vendor’s server or have physical access to the SIM card inventory.
Attacker must have radio line-of-sight to target for most accurate geolocation.
Adversary acquires credentials with legitimate privileges to conduct operations using the HSM. Adversary has a position to initiate transactions with the HSM.

column3: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB or UPF or SEPP or MME or any other core NF
column4: Adversary must have access to the network components to cause the attacks

column3: Access shared NF in a different slice
column4:
Two slices share one common NF that is able to get UE location info. Adversary has control of one slice or at least a NF in that slice -- where said NF is allowed to talk to the AMF.

The following core NFs can legitimately ask for or obtain directly the location of a UE (some granularity): AMF, UDM, NEF, NWDAF, GMLC, LMF. The following core NFs can only get limited/coarse location: SMF, UPF, PCF.
Privileged Access to VNF or VNF managers via direct login or thru Control Plane APIs

column3: Improper security monitoring of remote/shared facilities
column4: Remote/shared sites have to be integrated in the network-wide Security Incident and Monitoring System, but with additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider -level monitoring mechanisms. Failure to do so may leave advanced or sustained threats undetected, as well as technical failures or malfunctions of local resources.

Fibers routed between pieces of equipment without proper protection are susceptible to damage, which can critically affect network reliability. The fiber cable management system should therefore ensure that every fiber is protected from physical damage.

Lack of protection of junction boxes / splice closures. Improper cable routing also causes increased congestion in the termination panel and the cableways, increasing the possibility of bend radius violations and long-term failure.

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column4: An adversary must have control of the UPF IP address or a UPF

column2: Redirection of traffic via user plane network function
column4: An adversary must first control the SMF or NEF, or AF
Adversary must have identified a vulnerability susceptible to the specially crafted message that results in an ability to use additional techniques.
An adversary must already have compromised a trusted PLMN or one of their service providers, e.g. IPX, VAS, etc.
An adversary may need compromised legitimate credentials that could be used to obtain information from the MNO.
An adversary may need to identify a vulnerability in an MNO network function to send specially crafted requests to obtain initial access.
See technique Weaken Integrity: Network Interfaces
The end user must not have the capability to validate whether it is communicating with a malicious DNS or a valid one.
The end user must not have the capability to validate whether it is communicating with a malicious DNS or a valid one.

column3: Credential and Access to SDN Controller and network elements
column4: Privileged Access to SDN controller and Network elements
User security profile must allow bidding down.
Denying service to 5G and bidding down (e.g. from a fake or compromised base station) must have occurred for this 5G UE. Adversary must be present in the same area as the UE.

column3: Rogue or misconfigured AMF or SMF or gNB or MME
column4:
A rogue gNB may be required to change the UE’s CP & UP supported algorithms to NULL. It’s easier to achieve control over a gNB than over the AMF or SMF itself. But then if the AMF and SMF are not rogue just not configured to do these additional checks, then control over a rogue gNB is sufficient.
This attack is possible with only control over the AMF, in which case the algorithm for CP and UP protection may be changed to NULL.
Rogue or misconfigured SMSC
Adversary gets hold of an end point such as gNB to manipulate signaling
Adversary must first develop the malware to achieve the procedures herein.

column3: UE phone number and control of AF/NF
column4: Adversary has knowledge of UE phone number/GPSI and has control over an AF or NEF or AMF.

column2: Fraudulent AMF registration for UE in UDM
column4: If the UDM does not store the authentication status of a UE, or the authentication status is incorrect

column3: Ability to receive SUCI over the air

column3: Improper security monitoring of edge computing facilities
column4: Mobile-edge computing have to be integrated in the network-wide Security Incident and Monitoring System, but with additional considerations: development of use-case specific alert rules, integration and correlation of data at all levels (network, application), integration and correlation with service provider -level monitoring mechanisms. Failure to do so may leave advanced or sustained threats undetected, as well as technical failures or malfunctions of local resources.

column3: Control or misconfiguration of gNB or UPF
column4: Faulty implementation at gNB or UPF ; or, control over gNB, and UPF
Privileged access to device implementing the network separation controls

column3: Permissive subscriber security profile in the UE OR system employs null encryption.
column4: Subscriber security profile in the UE must allow bidding down to less secure service OR system must employ null encryption.
See [FGT1562.501](/techniques/FGT1562.501).
The end user does not have the capability to validate whether it is communicating with a malicious DNS or a valid one.

DNS traffic must be permitted to move through the network without verification that it is routed to valid DNS Servers and without checking to ensure that the contents of the packets are actually DNS requests.

column2: Unauthorized access to NEF via token fraud
column4: Access to some MNO services to gain knowledge about tokens to access the NEF
Adversary may need to compromise a base station to exploit the UE
Adversary may need to deploye and get UE to connect to adversary controlled base station.
NRF is by design open to connections from other network functions. Control of another NF in the operator domain may be required.
SCP is compromised to hijack tokens.

column2: Base station flood with fictitious access requests
column3: Transmit to gNB with sufficient power to succeed in flooding.
column4: Adversary must be able to transmit to gNB with sufficient power to be received.

column3: Permissive subscriber security profile OR system employs null integrity or encryption.

For NF discovery service, clause 5.2.7.1 of [3] lists the following service consumers: AMF, SMF, PCF, NEF, NSSF, SMSF, AUSF, CHF, NRF, NWDAF, I-CSCF, SCSCF, IMS-AS, SCP, UDM, AF, DCCF, MBSF, 5G DDNMF, TSCTSF.
